fol.192r
May it please yo
r
good L. After so muche deliberation as in my last
unto yo
r
L:
e 19 of this moneth I reported at large, The
States
deputed
M
r
Barnevelt
and
M
r
Vanderwerke
w
t
e Greffier of
their College, to acquaint me w
t
e tenor of two several l
res
w
ch
they hav e written to her
Ma
tie
and
e
LL. of
e Councell
.
it tending onely to excuse their protracting of their answear
to her Ma
ties
demandes, to shewe their curiousnes always
in observing the Contract, to foresignifie
e dangers, if
the people should be told
at her Ma
tie
would dissolve it,
and to intreate her to have patience will their State
will permitte
at they use a shorter course and to
give her better contentation, They requyred me w
th
all
w
t
a vehement kinde of speeche, That as I tendered
e
advancem
t
of her Hig
es
service: and
e good correspondence
between thes two contreis, and as I knewe their allegations
to be true and unfained, and found in conversation a hard
conceat
e people had of this demand of restitution, I
should second their l
res
w
t
others of myne owne, and
deale in
at behalf w
t
all sinceritie and roundenesse,
wherby her Hig
es
might forbeare from taking an extreme
or rigorous course against them. Whereunto for an
answear I signified againe,
at in all
t they desyred
I had done my duetie throughly by my former adver-
tisement
and had faithfully delivered all their
reasons to her Ma
tie
in every suche material point as
their l
res
made remonstrance: all which notw
th
stan-
ding her Hig
es
could not find, but if so be they would
endevor to persuade
e Generalitie, and therin use their
opportunities w
t
that dexteritiie and wisdome, as they are
wont in weightie causes, they might draw them to
e
payment of some convenient portion, wherby perhaps
she might be moved not to presse them for a while to
any further remoboursement. But when nothing at
all is presented
un
to her,
c
o
sidering her
long and chargeable succors,
and considering her present domesticall necessities,
with other manifold occasions of which they had bin by
me informed at full, and they of themselves could
make
e reckning well enough, it could not choose
but engender some notable alienation. Moreover, for
my self I had bin expressly charged, not to yeeld
or to hearken to any dilatorie answear, for w
ch
they
were not to attend my conveyance of their l
res
, nor
any other office,
at might any way seeme to favor their
present resolution. Of that which passed too and fro to
this effect, and
e lyke they made relation to their Col-
lege, who for ought I can perceave goe onward
fol.192v
with their purpose to send away those l
res
, which [I think]
they will consigne to their Agent
M
r
Caron
.
The
Councell of Estate
was very earnestly [bent to have]
sent unto her Ma
tie
some men of good account [and the]
States I am persuaded had followed
at counsai[le]
but
at
they stayed their proceeding upon my prohibi[tion.]
And thus remaining uncertaine w
at
course [of]
further dealing wilbe pleasing to her Ma
tie
I [will]
attend in
at behalf yo
r
L. good direction, and [take]
my humble leave.
From
e Hage 22 of Oc
t
.
